metadata.titleEn: Daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI and snow phenology dataset over High Mountain Asia （2000-2021）
metadata.description:
Snow cover is an important component of the cryosphere and an indispensable variable in the scientific research of global change and Earth system. The distribution range and phenological information of snow cover are important indicators to measure the variation characteristics of snow cover, and also important parameters for snow melting runoff simulation in the hydrological model of cold regions. The  High Mountain Asia is the source of many international rivers, and also the hot spot of global climate change research; The ecological and environmental problems caused by the change of ice and snow in the region, such as the reduction of water resources, the increase of extreme weather events, and the frequent occurrence of disasters, have attracted extensive attention from all countries. Therefore, it is very important for climate change research, water resources management, disaster early warning and prevention to accurately obtain long-term snow distribution and snow phenology data in  High Mountain Asia .
The daily cloudless MODIS normalized snow cover index (NDSI) product (2000-2021500 m) in the High Mountain Asia is based on the MODIS daily snow cover product (including Terra Morning Star data product MOD10A1 and Aqua Afternoon Star data product MYD10A1, C6 versions), and is processed by the same day afternoon star data fusion and cubic spline interpolation cloud removal algorithm; Among them, when there was only Morningstar data product MOD10A1 from 2000 to 2002, the cubic spline interpolation algorithm was directly used for cloud removal. The snow cover phenological data set for hydrological years 2002-2020 is prepared based on cloudless MODIS NDSI products in hydrological years, including three parameters:  snow onset date (SOD), snow end date (SED) and  snow duration days (SDD). This data set has reliable accuracy.
metadata.instructions:
MODIS NDSI data name: YYYYddd_ HMA_ MODIS_ NDSI_ 0.5km.img, where YYYY represents the year and ddd represents Julian day (001-365/366); Example: 2021009_ HMA_ MODIS_ NDSI_ 0.5km.img refers to MODIS NDSI products with a spatial resolution of 0.5km in the High Mountain Asia on January 9, 2021.
Name of snow cover phenological data: YYYY_ HMA_ MODIS_ SOD/SED/SDD_ 0.5km. Tif, where YYYY represents the year, SOD is the snow onset date, SED is the snow end date, and SDD is the  snow duration days ; For example: 2020_ HMA_ MODIS_ SOD_ 0.5km.tif refers to the MODIS snow onset date of the Asian alpine region in 2020 hydrological year (2020/9/1 to 2021/8/31) with a spatial resolution of 0.5km.
The file can be opened and viewed by ENVI or ARCGIS and other software.

background: Snow cover is a critical component of both the global energy and water cycles, covering about 40 to 50 % of the northern hemisphere during winter. Due to its high albedo and high emissivity as well as low thermal conductivity, snow cover has a large-scale cooling effect on the global climate system through strong interaction with the surface energy budget. Seasonal snow cover in high latitude and altitude regions in the northern and southern hemispheres is very sensitive to climate change. In this climate change context, the snow-covered extent (SCE) in the Northern Hemisphere has undergone significant reductions over the past decades and this trend will continue. HMA is the third largest cryosphere on earth outside of the Earth’s polar regions, known as the third pole of the earth, the birthplace of many great rivers, known as "Water Tower of Asia". As one of the most sensitive and prominent regions responding to global climate changes, HMA has experienced a considerable warming trend and the components of cryosphere (such as snow cover and glaciers) have been rapid shrinking over the last decades. Impacts of climate change on the cryosphere strongly led to changes in mountainous hydrological processes and water resources, and increased the HMA’s runoff due to the accelerated glacier/snowmelt.
research objective: The focus of this study is the detection and exhaustive analysis of spatiotemporal variability of the latest snow cover and snow phenology over HMA. Using the daily cloud-free MODIS snow cover products, the main objectives of this study are to (1) extract the snow cover parameters (SCE, SCD, SOD, SED and SDD) and analyse their spatiotemporal variations; (2) reveal the vertical difference of the relation of elevation to snow phenology; (3) to investigate the potential influence of climate factors on snow phenology variations.
challenges: The extensive cloud cover over snow-covered region is a critical issue that greatly limits the applications of the MODIS snow cover product to monitor the snow cover. The inconsistency between study region, time frame, and scale makes it a challenge for understanding where and how snow cover is changing.
methods: In this study, the same cloud-gap-filling strategy is used with the addition of the combination of MOD10A1 and MYD10A1 for the daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI product generation from 2002 to 2021. The SCD is calculated as the number of days a pixel is covered by snow in a hydrological year. During a hydrological year, the SOD is defined as the first date of the first five continuous snow cover days; the SED is defined as the last date of the last five continuous snow cover days; the SDD is defined as the duration days from SOD to SED.
dataset: The MODIS Terra and MODIS Aqua daily snow cover products (MOD10A1 and MYD10A1, Version C6) during 2002 – 2021 from NASA’s EOSDIS “Earthdata” are utilized in this study. The daily SD observed by 44 meteorological stations during 2002 – 2013 are used to extract the ground-observed snow phenology and are employed as ground truth to verify the performance of the snow phenology retrieved by daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI product.
findings: The results indicate that the monthly SCE over the whole HMA exhibited a slight decreasing in most months over the study period. The variability of snow cover and snow phenology over the whole HMA generally showed decreased SCD (significant decrease accounts for 15.73%), delayed SOD (significant delay accounts for 14.35%), advanced SED (significant advance accounts for 15.46%) and shortened SDD (significant shorten accounts for 16.01%). There is an elevation dependence of snow phenology changes over HMA with the high-altitude mountain ranges generally having a higher SCD, earlier SOD, later SED and longer SDD than low altitude areas. The air temperature of snow accumulation period is the dominant factor affecting the interannual variation of SOD, and the air temperature of snow melt period is the dominant factor affecting the interannual variation of SED. The increase of air temperature leads to the delayed SOD, advanced SED and shortened SDD.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain cloud-free snow cover information in high-altitude regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of a cloud-gap-filling strategy that combines the MOD10A1 and MYD10A1 products to generate daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products for high-altitude regions from 2002 to 2021.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using satellite data for snow cover monitoring in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: A common challenge is the extensive cloud cover over snow-covered regions, which significantly limits the application of MODIS snow cover products for monitoring purposes.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that serves as ground truth for validating satellite-derived snow phenology data?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the daily snow depth observed by 44 meteorological stations during 2002 – 2013, which is used to extract ground-observed snow phenology and verify the performance of snow phenology retrieved by daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products.

Feature Specification.Answer: daily cloud-free snow cover data, combination of MOD10A1 and MYD10A1 products, cloud-gap-filling strategy

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes of snow phenology are critical for understanding its spatiotemporal variability in high mountain Asian regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: snow cover extent, snow cover duration, snow onset date, snow end date, snow duration days

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'cloud-free MODIS snow cover products' in snow cover data collection?
Definition.Answer: Cloud-free MODIS snow cover products refer to data that have been processed to remove the influence of clouds, which can obscure snow cover in satellite images. This processing is crucial because extensive cloud cover greatly limits the applications of the MODIS snow cover product for monitoring snow cover. By using a cloud-gap-filling strategy and combining data from MOD10A1 and MYD10A1, researchers can generate daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products, improving the accuracy and reliability of snow cover monitoring.

Definition.Question: What does 'snow phenology' mean in the context of high mountain Asia (HMA) research?
Definition.Answer: Snow phenology refers to the study of seasonal patterns and timing of snow cover, including parameters such as the snow cover extent (SCE), snow cover duration (SCD), snow onset date (SOD), snow end date (SED), and snow duration days (SDD). This involves analyzing the spatiotemporal variations of snow cover and understanding how these are influenced by factors such as elevation and climate change, particularly in sensitive regions like high mountain Asia (HMA).

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques used in generating daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products compare to those used in collecting ground-observed snow phenology data from meteorological stations?
Comparison.Answer: The daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products are generated using a combination of MOD10A1 and MYD10A1 data and a cloud-gap-filling strategy from satellite observations, whereas ground-observed snow phenology data are collected from meteorological stations that directly observe snow depth, providing ground truth for validation.

Comparison.Question: How does the spatiotemporal variability analysis of snow phenology using MODIS data compare to that using ground-based data in terms of resolution and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: MODIS data allows for a broad spatiotemporal analysis with high resolution over large areas, capturing variability in snow phenology across diverse terrains, but may require interpolation techniques to address cloud cover gaps. Ground-based data provides high accuracy at specific locations, serving as a reliable reference for validating satellite-derived snow phenology.

Interpretation.Question: How can the combination of MODIS Terra and Aqua daily snow cover products enhance the accuracy of snow phenology data collection in high-altitude regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The combination of MODIS Terra and Aqua daily snow cover products allows for the creation of daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products. This method uses data from both morning (Terra) and afternoon (Aqua) satellites, along with a cloud-gap-filling strategy, to ensure more comprehensive and accurate snow cover observations, crucial for high-altitude regions where cloud cover can otherwise impede data collection.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise from using MODIS data products for monitoring snow cover and how might these affect the interpretation of snow phenology patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: A major challenge is the extensive cloud cover over snow-covered regions, which limits the application of MODIS snow cover products for accurate monitoring. This can affect the interpretation of snow phenology patterns by introducing inconsistencies in data coverage and temporal resolution, potentially skewing the understanding of snow cover changes in terms of spatial and temporal variations.

Interpretation.Question: What role does elevation play in the interpretation of snow phenology changes, and how can data collection methods be adapted to account for these variations?
Interpretation.Answer: Elevation plays a significant role in snow phenology changes, with high-altitude areas generally exhibiting higher SCD, earlier SOD, later SED, and longer SDD compared to lower altitudes. Data collection methods can be adapted by incorporating elevation-specific analysis to account for these variations, ensuring that the influence of altitude on snow cover dynamics is accurately captured and interpreted.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges associated with the use of MODIS snow cover products for monitoring snow cover in the Asian high mountains?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The extensive cloud cover over snow-covered regions is a critical issue that greatly limits the applications of the MODIS snow cover product to monitor the snow cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to understand where and how snow cover is changing in the Asian high mountains?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The inconsistency between study region, time frame, and scale makes it a challenge for understanding where and how snow cover is changing.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a cloud-gap-filling strategy on the accuracy and reliability of snow cover and snow phenology data in high-altitude regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a cloud-gap-filling strategy, combined with data from MODIS Terra and Aqua, allows for the generation of daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products, which can enhance the accuracy and reliability of snow phenology data in high-altitude regions. This method mitigates issues related to extensive cloud cover, enhancing the monitoring capabilities of snow cover changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary intention behind utilizing daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products for snow cover analysis in the Asian high mountains?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives of using daily cloud-free MODIS snow cover products are to extract snow cover parameters and analyze their spatiotemporal variations, reveal the relation of snow phenology to elevation, and investigate the potential influence of climate factors on snow phenology variations over the High Mountain Asia (HMA) region.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the challenges of cloud cover when monitoring snow cover using remote sensing techniques?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Extensive cloud cover over snow-covered regions is a critical issue that limits the application of MODIS snow cover products for monitoring. Addressing this challenge is crucial for understanding snow cover changes across different regions and time frames, which is essential for accurate climate change research and water resource management.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of integrating ground-based meteorological data with remote sensing data in snow phenology studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of integrating ground-based meteorological data with remote sensing data is to verify the performance of snow phenology retrieved by remote sensing products. This integration helps in extracting ground-observed snow phenology, which serves as ground truth, enhancing the reliability and accuracy of snow phenology assessments over the study area.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in generating a cloud-free MODIS NDSI product for monitoring snow cover in high-altitude Asian regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using a cloud-gap-filling strategy that combines data from MOD10A1 and MYD10A1 products. The data fusion is done for the same day from the Terra and Aqua satellites, followed by the application of a cubic spline interpolation algorithm to remove cloud cover, generating a cloud-free daily MODIS NDSI product from 2002 to 2021.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the spatiotemporal variability of snow cover parameters be effectively analyzed using satellite data in the context of climate change research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The analysis can be conducted by extracting snow cover parameters such as snow-covered extent (SCE), snow cover duration (SCD), snow onset date (SOD), snow end date (SED), and snow duration days (SDD) from the daily cloud-free MODIS snow cover products. These parameters are then evaluated for their spatiotemporal variations and related to elevation differences and climate factors.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to verify the accuracy of snow phenology data extracted from satellite imagery in high mountain regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The verification process involves comparing the snow phenology data retrieved from the daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI product with ground-observed snow phenology data. This ground truth data is obtained from the daily snow depth observations recorded by 44 meteorological stations during the period from 2002 to 2013.

Enablement.Question: What data integration techniques enable the generation of cloud-free snow cover datasets in high-altitude regions?
Enablement.Answer: The combination of MODIS Terra and Aqua daily snow cover products (MOD10A1 and MYD10A1) along with a cloud-gap-filling strategy and cubic spline interpolation are used to generate cloud-free MODIS NDSI products, enabling the study of snow cover in high-altitude regions.

Enablement.Question: How do meteorological station observations contribute to the validation of snow phenology datasets in challenging terrains?
Enablement.Answer: Observations from meteorological stations are used to extract ground-observed snow phenology, which serves as ground truth to verify the performance of snow phenology retrieved by daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products, thus contributing to the dataset's validation in challenging terrains.

Enablement.Question: What challenges in snow-covered regions affect the application of satellite-derived snow cover data, and how are these challenges addressed?
Enablement.Answer: The extensive cloud cover over snow-covered regions is a critical issue that limits the application of MODIS snow cover products. This challenge is addressed by employing a combination of MOD10A1 and MYD10A1 products and a cloud-gap-filling strategy to generate cloud-free data.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for the observed spatiotemporal variability in snow cover and snow phenology over high mountain regions in Asia?
Expectation.Answer: The spatiotemporal variability in snow cover and snow phenology over high mountain regions in Asia can be attributed to factors such as climate change, which affects snow cover extent, duration, and timing. Specifically, air temperature during the snow accumulation and melt periods is the dominant factor influencing changes in snow onset and end dates, as well as the duration of snow cover.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be an elevation dependence of snow phenology changes in high-altitude mountain ranges?
Expectation.Answer: Elevation dependence in snow phenology changes is likely because high-altitude mountain ranges tend to have a higher snow cover duration (SCD), earlier snow onset dates (SOD), later snow end dates (SED), and longer snow duration days (SDD) compared to lower altitude areas. The variations in temperature and precipitation patterns with elevation significantly impact these snow phenology parameters.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using a cloud-gap-filling strategy in generating daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products for snow cover analysis in high-altitude regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The cloud-gap-filling strategy, combined with the integration of MOD10A1 and MYD10A1 products, has proven effective in generating daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI products. This approach addresses the significant challenge posed by extensive cloud cover in snow-covered regions, thereby improving the monitoring capabilities of snow cover in high-altitude areas.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges you foresee in utilizing MODIS Terra and Aqua daily snow cover products for detecting spatiotemporal variability of snow phenology?
Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenges include handling the extensive cloud cover over snow-covered regions, which can limit the use of MODIS products. Additionally, there may be inconsistencies between different study regions, time frames, and scales that complicate understanding snow cover changes. Addressing these challenges requires robust data processing techniques and careful interpretation of results.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the cloud-gap-filling strategy is effectively used in generating a reliable daily cloud-free dataset for snow cover analysis.
Assertion.Answer: The cloud-gap-filling strategy involves merging MODIS Terra (MOD10A1) and Aqua (MYD10A1) daily snow cover products to create a daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI product from 2002 to 2021. The use of both datasets and interpolation techniques, like the cubic spline interpolation, help in reducing cloud cover impact, enhancing the reliability of the snow cover data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the process and importance of verifying snow phenology data with ground-truth observations.
Assertion.Answer: Ground-truth verification is crucial for ensuring the accuracy of snow phenology data derived from satellite observations. In this domain, daily snow depth observed by 44 meteorological stations from 2002 to 2013 is used as ground truth to validate the snow phenology metrics obtained from the daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI product, which enhances the credibility of the satellite-derived data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how elevation impacts the snow cover duration and other phenology measures in high-altitude regions.
Assertion.Answer: Elevation significantly affects snow phenology measures. In high-altitude mountain ranges, snow cover duration (SCD) tends to be longer, with an earlier start of snow cover (SOD) and a later end (SED), resulting in a longer snow duration (SDD) compared to lower altitude areas. This elevation dependence is due to temperature variations and other climatic factors that change with elevation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection techniques used to obtain daily cloud-free snow cover information in high-altitude Asian regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve the fusion of MODIS Terra (MOD10A1) and Aqua (MYD10A1) daily snow cover products, employing a cloud-gap-filling strategy with cubic spline interpolation to generate a daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI product for the years 2002 to 2021.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in monitoring snow phenology in high-altitude Asian regions using remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include extensive cloud cover over snow-covered regions, which limits the application of MODIS snow cover products for monitoring. There is also inconsistency in the study region, time frame, and scale, making it difficult to understand changes in snow cover.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that can be used alongside MODIS data to enhance the accuracy of snow phenology assessments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include the daily snow depth (SD) observations from meteorological stations, which can be used to extract ground-observed snow phenology and serve as ground truth to verify the performance of snow phenology retrieved by the daily cloud-free MODIS NDSI product.
